title: The ultra-rare Honus Wagner card with local ties just sold for a world-record-breaking amount
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: A 1909 Honus Wagner baseball card sold for $5.12 million, setting a record for a PSA 1 graded card.
The card was originally owned by Morton Bernstein and passed down to his grandsons, Dennis and Douglas Shields.
Ken Goldin's auction house facilitated the sale, which broke the previous PSA 1 sale record by $2 million.

title: ICE deportees reportedly held on N.H. tarmac for more than 12 hours during storm
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: A plane with 100 ICE detainees was stranded at Portsmouth International Airport, N.H., for over 30 hours due to a winter storm.
Detainees were kept on the tarmac for 13 hours before moving to a terminal, receiving meals and medical checks.
Portsmouth Assistant Mayor and community members were denied access to check on detainees, despite concerns over their treatment.

title: Reggie Miller: Celtics are ‘scariest’ team in the East with or without Jayson Tatum
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Boston Celtics have won nine of their last ten games and are second in the Eastern Conference standings.
Reggie Miller states Celtics are the 'scariest' Eastern team with or without Jayson Tatum due to their strong performance.
Jaylen Brown is considered an MVP contender, averaging 29.2 points, 7 rebounds, and 4.7 assists per game.

title: $7 million Chatham house has a private sandy beach: ‘Super desirable and rare’
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: Historic Chatham house at 150 Main Street listed for $6.95 million, featuring a private sandy beach.
Built around 1840, the 2,552-square-foot Cape-style home offers seven bedrooms and 2.5 bathrooms.
Property includes 75 feet of beach frontage and is part of Chatham's Village Historic District.

title: A social media post about a traveler’s ‘masterclass in boundaries’ on a flight out of Maine goes viral
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: A social media post by @digbymomma about boundaries on a flight departing Maine went viral with 31,000 likes.
The post described a woman's firm response to a male passenger invading her personal space, prompting widespread support.
Commenters shared personal stories of boundary issues during travel, highlighting the need for clear communication.

title: Is your home ready for this winter?
author: Zipporah Osei
bullets: Boston's snow total reaches over 60 inches, highest since 'Snowmageddon' 2015.
Winter Home Guide provides tips for managing snow loads, ice dams, and frozen gardens.
Boston extends parking ban until 6 p.m. Tuesday amid ongoing blizzard conditions.

title: What Boston meteorologists are saying about the timing and impacts of Wednesday’s snow
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: A quick burst of snow will drop 1-3 inches in southern New England Wednesday morning.
Snow is expected to mix with rain, mainly affecting the south coast, reducing visibility and making roads slick.
Temperatures will rise into the 30s today, with a milder weekend expected before an arctic blast on Sunday.

title: Some changes are in store for Kendall Square Cinema
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Landmark Theatres will begin modernizing Kendall Square Cinema in Cambridge starting March, aiming for completion by late summer 2026.
Upgrades include larger screens, luxury recliners, expanded menu, and a revamped auditorium with a giant-format screen and event stage.
Renovations will replace the box office with a video arcade and add a full-service bar, party room, and updated storefront displays.

title: View Boston to shutter observatory restaurants, cut 79 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: View Boston is closing its observatory restaurants, impacting 79 jobs, to focus on private event spaces.
The layoffs at the Prudential Center observatory will affect 41 full-time and 38 part-time employees by April 22.
The observatory reopened in 2023 after a $182 million renovation but will now cater to growing demand for private events.

title: Alex Cora was impressed by Ranger Suarez in limited spring training debut for Red Sox
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Ranger Suarez made his Red Sox spring training debut, pitching 1 2/3 innings, allowing three hits and two runs.
Suarez recently signed a five-year, $130 million contract with the Red Sox and is set to pitch in the World Baseball Classic.
Red Sox manager Alex Cora praised Suarez's composure, noting his calm presence and competitive nature on the mound.
